summary: Hawthorne College is quieting down for the holidays as students travel home to spend time with their families. Black Christmas, both the 1974 and the 2006 movies where slasher movies that took a Christmasy slant on the formula of the slasher genre, and knowing this, I went into this movie with certain expectations

What I was met with was contrived, obvious, and awful. Whereas previous titles with the black Christmas title focused on the typical formula, introducing the character, then introducing the killer, followed by the arrival of the killer, and then chaos ensues, in this instance, the movie mainly follows a single character, who was the victim of a sexual assault, rather obviously but no one believes her.

This leads to the typical buildup to the final attack where our 'heroines?' home is invaded by a hooded figure, after a short struggle and one of the girls being killed, they stop the killer and before they can unmask him, another rises to take his place, there's more of them *edit in the overly dramatic hamster here*.

This leads to the final showdown where the plot basically boils down to "awful professor is an awful person, the frat is using a dark magic ritual to control new pledges minds" then the strong character makes her triumphant return and the final battle insues, where the item controlling the men is destroyed.

Bueno pues aquí estamos...criticando una de las cintas más polarizantes del año pasado. Algo que no tendría porque serlo pero dado la gran carga de mensaje politico y social que hay en ella, algo así era inevitable.

Curiosamente, lo que para algunos en esta cinta es algo metido con la sutileza de un elefante en una cacharrería, a mi me parece que refleja bastante bien la realidad social en la que vivimos.

Una vez dicho esto...la película es mala. Ni siquiera el excelente trabajo de Imogen Poots (y algunas de sus compañeras de reparto), que sostiene casi por si sola la película es suficiente para arreglar el desastre en lo demás. El guión es pobretón y simplón, salvando algunos elementos que podrían verse como inteligente reflejos (y ataques) a la cultura más machista e incel. 

El trabajo de cámara en combinación con la edición es desastroso. No solo tenemos planos faltos de expresividad (o directamente mal encuadrados), sino que restan de toda tensión posible en la cinta. De hecho, el único momento en el que vi algun retazo de creatividad visual, es un "homenaje" al Exorcista III. No tengo problemas con que sea un calco, hemos visto cosas similares antes y entiendo el guiño, pero dice poco de tu película que el momenta más interesante a nivel estíslitico esté sacado de otra cinta.

Cierto cambos en la trama intentaban hacer algo diferente a la original al mismo tiempo que servir de una graciosa anología paródica a compartamientos sociales poco encomiables actuales...sin embargo acaban jugando en contra de la cinta, haciéndola mucho más tontorrona, menos creible, y además casi contradice parte del mensaje que quieres mandar...

Entiendo también que la película tuvo bastante problemas a nivel de producción y mucha mano de estudio detrás, lo cual no ayudó para nada...Aun así...horriblemente fallida, lo que me da mucha pena.

Sophia Takal directs with a deft cinematic hand, motivating a lot of her shots with interesting camera movements and creepy background elements that leave the film a solid cut above your usual horror flick. Oh, HELL YEAH, IT DOES.
Once the admittedly limited thrills start to bleed out, 'Black Christmas' turns into a glorious cartoon about my, ahem, favorite pair of words in the English language: toxic masculinity. Up until around the movie's halfway mark, Takal and April Wolfe's screenplay holds up okay, with only the occasionally grating super-uber-mega-duper "smash the patriarchy" remark trickling out from Aleyse Shannon's plain awfully written character, Kris. If her degree of unabashed "wokeness" wasn't enough by then, when the spookiness and ridiculously nutty plot reveals start to hit, the movie's true narrative awakens and turns the piece into the purest, most splendorous schlock I've had the pleasure of experiencing in 2019. Neither 'Hellboy,' nor 'Serenity' can match the insane wonders here afoot, no sir.

The second remake now of Black Christmas (1974) a film that some may say started the slasher film genre. This film keeps with the theme of strong woman protagonists and characters that aren't the typical kind of characters you find in these kind of movies, but it definitely takes a sharp left during its third act. It's Christmas time at Hawthorne College, so that means everyone is going on Winter Break for the end of the Fall Semester. We follow Riley (Imogen Poots) who is staying behind with her fellow sisters Kris (Aleyse Shannon), Marty (Lily Donoghue) and Jesse (Brittany O'Grady). Riley is an orphan, so her sorority is really all she has. Riley herself had a traumatic experience involving the local AKO Fraternity President Brian  (Ryan McIntyre). The girls decide to play a prank on the fraternity and soon after begin receiving very disturbing text messages. Girls in the nearby sororities start to be picked off by a masked killer one by one. The killer eventually finds himself at Rileys sorority and gives them a night they soon won't forget. There's actually quite a bit more plot to this, but I don't want to ruin it. The film works a lot because Poots is really good here. She's very likeable and is resourceful. I enjoyed her and while I think the plot is ridiculous (especially when you find out some secrets revealed) I still think it's one of those horror films that knows it's cheesy and you kind of just go with it. It's predictable and at times very campy, but it works. It definitely went a different direction than the original and for this kind of movie it works. I think the movie would have benefited by staying with a R rating. The PG-13 rating here really takes away from the kills (often times a lot of it happening off screen). For the most part I would say horror fans should give this one a rental at the very least when it releases for home release.

The four pillars that create a good movie were all missing in this film. Firstly, the plot was severely lacking in depth and in structure, neither establishing a compelling narrative nor properly pacing it.  The first 45 minutes of the movie set up a myriad of incongruent, half-baked ideas.  These were promptly abandoned when, in the second half, the sorority girls took to extreme combat with mysterious hooded figures.  The gruesome fates that befell numerous sisters unfortunately fell flat with the audience, as the lack of character development made it too easy to say goodbye to these girls.
Better characterization was the second thing that this movie needed.  Beyond the main trio - who stood out only due to the quantity of lines, not the quality - it was difficult to recognize individual characters because there was no development.  Not a single character showed any sort of dimensionality or growth throughout the movie.
The third component that this movie sorely lacked was a well-written script.  Stereotypical and uninspired, the lines in this movie made it more reminiscent of a comedy than the horror film it so clearly wanted to be.  At the most suspenseful and dramatic moments, the sheer silliness of the dialogue cut through all tension. Lastly, the cinematography was flat, uninteresting, and at times so cliché it added to the comedic atmosphere created by the poor writing. Overall, this movie failed to create a cohesive storyline, populate it with captivating characters and intriguing dialogue, and to exhibit anything above rudimentary videography skills.

Whilst the film was advertised as being a freshly done take on the 1974 original film of the same name by Bob Clark, it largely strays away from the original source material. In fact, it entirely deviates from the concept of Black Christmas. It is important to note that while there are subtle hints of disdain with the dominance of classic patriarchal archetypes in the 1974 film, the focus of the film was entirely a horror piece, intended to evoke unease and shock in its audience. The 2019 film completely throws the concept of its source to the side and trades it in for a surprisingly cringeworthy attempt at showcasing the horrors of "toxic masculinity". The film begins as a slow-burn style slasher, even recreating certain shots of the original film, only occasionally peppering the viewer with meta-commentary on the social injustices a patriarchal society inflicts upon women today. As the film progresses, it phones-in more of a socio-political commentary more akin to the television series 'Scream Queens', with its sub-focus revolving around feminism and empowering women rather than comedy. I have nothing wrong with feminist concepts and female empowerment in films or even horror films...If it is done correctly and tastefully, it needs to be nuanced and done with subtlety. Black Christmas (2019) is a cringey and contrived attempt at establishing a feminist's "f*ck the man" film in modern horror. This movie used the beloved title of 'Black Christmas' as a catchy brand, just to push a narrative about gender politics. Other than their settings, the 2019 film bears no similarity to the original film or even the 2005 remake and is only 'Black Christmas' in its name. A lot of concepts and ideas are taken very far in this film and it falls entirely beyond the scope of horror that the original Christmas time slasher-film brought to the table. At its core, it serves to become yet another classic IP being tarnished and assimilated by a blindly aggressive feminist agenda in cinema.

An arrow is whizzing your way. Robin Hood would be repulsed. The ghost of bad Calvin Hawthorne, condensed into coal dust from landing one too many years on Santa’s naughty list, mucks amok. Eventually the story shifts from women-as-victims to women-as-attackers. But not before they turn on each other, taking a respite from arrows and axes and knives to argue and bicker. Picture this, you and your BFF, nearly slasher fodder, escape by commandeering a car and are racing for your lives down a dark, isolated wintery road. Now one of you must walk for your life. Oh, please. Da-dum-dum-dum, dum, dumb. Her foolish move drags Little Drummer Boy into the fray. Don’t worry. The disgruntled walker survives, appearing in the next scene slogging menacingly towards the AKO voodoo brothers with a snow shovel slung over her shoulder, the weapon du jour. Visualize a shovel-toting Annie Oakley in a Santa cap. Hard to imagine....unless you’ve seen Black Christmas. The film ends with the sisterhood unified in fiery defiance. Black Christmas is a 2019 Holiday Slasher film directed by Sophia Takal and written by Takal and April Wolfe. It’s the third remake of the original 1974 film of the same name but is a fundamentally different movie in a lot of ways. It has a more fast paced style and a completely different story it’s trying to tell. Only a few things tie the three films together, the Christmas theme and the fact that it takes place in a sorority house where people get murdered. The film was written and shot with an R rating in mind but was changed after test screenings to be PG-13, and it shows. A lot of the kill scenes are cut abruptly short in a way that’s extremely distracting taking away from the film makers intended vision. Slasher films don’t need to be gory to work, Halloween (1978) and the original Black Christmas are great examples of that, but when a film is re-edited to become something that it’s not it because of committee think (cough cough Blumhouse), it comes off cynical and ruins the impact the creators wanted it to have. The writing of this film is completely bonkers, it goes to places that border on schlock and come off comical, which I wasn’t expecting due to the serious subject matter. It takes on rape culture in fraternities and toxic masculinity in general which is a real issue that can fit well into a horror movie like this, but it was handled so broadly to the point where it felt like a parody of itself. One thing I really liked about the film was the way it looked; some of the later scenes are bathed in green or red as Christmas lights illuminate character’s faces and the environment, and it looked great. There we’re probably some good things in there, but its buried by re-edits and a ridiculous plot that doesn’t take its subject matter as seriously as it should. Imogen Poots is great as always and does her best to keep this movie afloat along with the pretty cinematography, but sadly, it’s just another remake.
